Award.AwardTitle: Adaptive and High-Spectral Efficiency Communications by Optical Arbitrary Waveform Generation and Measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate a new ultra-high capacity communication technology that can scale beyond terabit per second capacity, withstand physical layer impairments, and flexibly support diverse data flows. The project combines new and scalable optical arbitrary waveform generation techniques together with microwave communications, signal processing, and coding techniques. The resulting terascale system effectively accommodates high and low data flow traffic and mitigates physical layer impairments. The project will also investigate CMOS-compatible silicon based optical integration, and will pursue future integration of electronic and photonic functions to realize more compact and agile functions on a chip scale system.

The intellectual merit of this research is in the theoretical and experimental investigations of hardware and software, and in studying photonic and electronic solutions for future terascale communication systems with resiliency, flexibility, and scalability. Furthermore, the project will also pursue significant enhancement in signal processing capability by combining best opportunities in both optics and electronics. The results of this project will provide a new insight into optical-electronic communication technologies, hardware-software codesign, silicon photonic integrated circuits, and future prospects for resulting communication, computing, and information technology of the future.

The broader impacts of this research are as follows: (1) transforming the way of design, implementation, and operation of healthcare, data center networking, and cloud computing, (2) making available compact communication tools fabricated by CMOS foundry to provide rapid and widespread benefits to the society, (3) bringing new communication theory and algorithm crosscutting optics, electronics, and computing framework, (4) developing new courses to disseminate the up-to-date knowledge on communications and optoelectronics, (5) introducing opportunity for underrepresented and high-school students to be involved in state-of-the-art technology research and education, and (6) stimulating new opportunities towards realizing intelligent terascale communication systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made comprehensive studies of very high-performance RF-photonic communication modules incorporating novel effects of RF-photonic optical comb generation and RF-photonic arbitrary optical waveform generation and measurement, novel digital signal processing techniques, and new optical integrated devices.  Specifically, the PIs and the research team focused on:

  • Simulation and proof-of concept experimental demonstration of the RF-photonic techniques for optical frequency comb generation, dynamic optical arbitrary waveform generation (see Figure 1) and dynamic optical arbitrary waveform measurement (see Figure 2).
  • Design, simulation studies and fabrication of RF-photonic devices to implement a new class of communications module using RF-Photonic optical comb generation and RF-photonic arbitrary optical waveform encoding (see Figure 3). The team exploited advanced hybrid integration technologies and platforms to achieve high-speed RF and high-performance optical waveguides.
  • System and networking studies on the benefits and applications of the proposed communication modules in fiber optical communication networks.

The research carried out in this project provided theoretical and experimental studies of RF-photonic communications modules capable of generating and measuring very-large bandwidth signals (hundreds of GHz) while using reasonably low-speed (< 20 GHz) opto-electronic components.  Significant progress have been made also in terms of fabrication techniques on hybrid integration platforms in order to achieve high performance in terms on energy efficiency, loss, bandwidth, and signal fidelity. The project involved synergetic design, analysis, simulation, prototyping and testing activities in both RF and optical technologies.  Finally, through integrated systems and networking studies, the research team investigated and analyzed how these new components can be used to implement next-generation telecommunication transceivers and bring significant benefits in terms of network throughput performance, latency, and energy efficiency.

The progress in this project provided an opportunity for the students and faculties to gain a comprehensive understanding of RF photonic devices and resulting communications systems and impact of future communication networks. 

The research activities and results have been linked with education activities at UC Davis carried out by the PIs for both graduate and undergraduate classes as Semiconductor Lasers, Optical Fiber Communications Technologies, Optical Fiber Communications Systems and Networking, Optical Communications I: Fibers, Optoelectronics and Fiber Optics Laboratory, and Signals and Communications.

The proposed project has provided an exciting opportunity to train students in designing, developing, and testing applications on a futuristic networking platform.  Throughout the process, students has the opportunity to learn how to distribute their knowledge to their peers, attending and presenting the project results at international conferences and workshops, and publishing peer-reviewed papers. The research efforts carried out during this project led to the publication of more than 20 papers in high-impact factor journals and top-level international conferences in USA, Europe and Asia.
